name: Common Squirrel Monkey
description: It has a slender body and limbs, short fur, and a strikingly round head. Its base color is gray-brown with an olive tint, hands and feet are yellow. The white face contrasts with dark eyes and a black nose.
spread_note: Tropical South America except southeastern Brazil
proportions: Body length 23–37 cm; tail length 36–47 cm; weight 0.6–1.4 kg
attractions: The squirrel monkey is an agile little primate that spends most of its day foraging high in tree canopies in groups of up to 50 individuals. It moves through branches with leaps, steering with its long tail, which, unlike many other South American monkeys, is not prehensile. They feed on sap, flowers, fruits, and insects, often deftly catching flying insects with their forepaws. Troops consist of females, usually several males, and young. During mating season, males engage in fierce fights. Squirrel monkeys communicate with a wide range of vocalizations, including bird-like chirps. They sometimes form mixed groups with other monkey species, most often capuchins.
breeding: Squirrel monkeys were kept from 1990–1995 and then again from 2004 or 2005, when two pairs arrived (the female Japonečka from this group still lives at the zoo). The first successful breeding occurred in 2006.
